common.thank_you_for_joining: Thank you for joining Project Singular!
common.closing1: If you have questions at any point and would like to talk to a member of our study staff, please reach out to us at
common.closing1_you_or_child: If you or your child have questions at any point and would like to talk to a member of our study staff, please reach out to us at

welcome.subject: Welcome! Your account has been created.
welcome.p1: You have successfully created an account. If you haven’t already, the next step is to begin enrollment for a participant by clicking on an enrollment button on the Project Singular dashboard. Participants that can be enrolled include:
welcome.list_li1_li1: You have a single ventricle defect; or
welcome.list_li1_li2: You have a biological child with a single ventricle defect; or
welcome.list_li1_li3: You have a biological sibling with a single ventricle defect.
welcome.list_li2_li1: That child has a single ventricle defect; or
welcome.list_li2_li2: That child is the biological sibling of an individual with a single ventricle defect; or
welcome.list_li2_li3: That child has a biological parent with a single ventricle defect.
welcome.p2: Please note that you can enroll multiple children if you have more than one child who meets the criteria above.
welcome.p3: After adding a participant, you will be asked to read the research consent form where we explain in detail what will happen in this study and ask for your agreement to participate.
welcome.p4: Please click the following link to return to your Project Singular dashboard to begin enrollment of you or your child.

consent_reminder_self.subject: Please sign the consent form
consent_reminder_self.p1: We have previously sent you a link to read and sign the consent form and have not heard back from you. We are resending the link in case it was missed. This is the next step in the process to enroll in Project Singular. Please click the following link to return to Project Singular to read and sign the Consent Form.

consent_reminder_child.subject: Please sign the consent form

This is the next step in the process to enroll your child in Project Singular. Please click the following link to return to Project Singular to read and sign the Consent Form.

about_me_reminder.subject: Please complete a form
about_me_reminder.p1: The next step in completing your enrollment in Project Singular is to answer a few short questions in a section called “About Me”. If you haven’t yet had a chance to complete this questionnaire, please click on the following link to return to Project Singular to do so now.

about_my_child_reminder.subject: Please complete a form
about_my_child_reminder.p1: The next step in completing your child’s enrollment in Project Singular is to answer a few short questions in a section called “About My Child.” If you haven’t yet had a chance to complete this questionnaire, please click on the following link to return to Project Singular to do so now.

medical_release_reminder_self.subject: Please complete a form

medical_release_reminder_self.p2: The next step is to complete a Medical Record Release Form so that we may request and receive copies of your medical records.
medical_release_reminder_self.p3: If you haven’t already done so, please click the following link to return to Project Singular to complete your medical release form.

parental_medical_release_reminder.subject: Please complete a form

parental_medical_release_reminder.p2: The next step is to complete a Medical Record Release Form so that we may request and receive copies of your child’s medical records.
parental_medical_release_reminder.p3: If you haven’t already done so, please click the following link to return to Project Singular to complete your child’s medical release form.

completion_thank_you_self.subject: Thank you for providing your information!
completion_thank_you_self.p1: Thank you again for enrolling and submitting your information! You are now fully enrolled in Project Singular! If you have not yet submitted your medical records, our partners at Boston Children’s Hospital will be reaching out to you shortly to provide assistance in obtaining those records.
completion_thank_you_self.p2: We’re on a mission to accelerate research into single ventricle heart defects. By contributing your unique health information, you are contributing to a growing community of patients and families committed to finding solutions for single ventricle heart disease.
completion_thank_you_self.p3: Soon, you will be receiving a saliva (spit) donation kit by mail. All of the instructions you will need to collect and return your sample will be included, along with a postage paid return envelope.
completion_thank_you_self.p4: If at any time you would like to check back to visit your dashboard, please feel free to do so using the link below. We plan to periodically post updates on the Project Singular website to keep all participants informed as to our study progress.
completion_thank_you_self.p5: Please note, all information you have provided to us on the Project Singular website will be secure and encrypted.

If you have not yet submitted your child’s medical records, our partners at Boston Children’s Hospital will be reaching out to you shortly to provide assistance in obtaining those records.

completion_thank_you_child.p3: Soon, you will be receiving a saliva (spit) donation kit by mail. All of the instructions you will need to collect and return your child’s sample will be included, along with a postage paid return envelope.
completion_thank_you_child.p4: If at any time you would like to check back to visit your dashboard, please feel free to do so using the link below. We plan to periodically post updates on the Project Singular website to keep all participants informed as to our study progress.
completion_thank_you_child.p5: Please note, all information you have provided to us on the Project Singular website will be secure and encrypted.

sample_received_self.p2: If you have not yet heard from Boston Children’s Hospital in regards to obtaining your medical records, they will be in touch with you shortly to provide assistance.
sample_received_self.p3: Thank you again for your participation in Project Singular! We hope to learn a great deal about single ventricle heart disease through Project Singular, and you are playing a critically important role.

So that we may contact them about the upcoming re-consent process, please click on the link below to provide us with your child’s email address:

consent_child_age_of_majority.p4: We’re on a mission to accelerate research into single ventricle heart defects and appreciate your contributions.

We will need to have them sign their own consent form at the time of their birthday if they are to continue their participation in the study.

consent_child_age_of_majority_email_veri.p1: Your parent has previously enrolled you in Project Singular and has provided us with your contact email address. Project Singular is a research study seeking to understand why some individuals are born with a single ventricle heart defect. Your parent enrolled you because either you or an immediate family member has single ventricle heart disease.
consent_child_age_of_majority_email_veri.p2: You will soon be reaching the age when you can decide whether or not to enroll yourself as an adult. At that point, we will ask you to sign a new consent form so that you may continue to participate in the study.

consent_self.name: Consent
consent_self.title:
PROJECT SINGULAR
RESEARCH CONSENT FORM

intro.p1: Affected Adults and Adults Who Are Immediate Family Members of Affected Individuals
intro.p3: Principal Investigator: Kirstie E Keller, PhD
intro.p6: Please carefully read the consent form below. Click “Next” when you are done with this page. If you have questions about Project Singular or this form, please ask us. You can call us at (650) 761-6486. Or you can email us at contact@projectsingular.org.
intro.p7p2: a PDF version of the consent form and read it carefully.

consent_self.summary_created: Signing this informed consent document is required if you wish to enroll.
consent_self.summary_in_progress: Signing this informed consent document is required if you wish to enroll.
consent_self.summary_complete: Thank you for signing the consent form -- you are now enrolled!

summary.title: RESEARCH CONSENT SUMMARY
summary.p1: In this consent form, “you” always refers to the person participating in the study. If you are a legally authorized representative (such as a guardian), please remember that “you” refers to the study participant.
summary.p2: We are asking you to take part in a research study. We are asking for one of three reasons. You may have a single ventricle heart defect. Or you are a close family member (birth child, sibling, or parent) of someone with a single ventricle heart defect. Or you are a parent or guardian of someone with a single ventricle heart defect.
summary.p3: Taking part in the study is all by choice. You can choose if you want to take part or not. You can quit the study at any time.
summary.p4: The goal of this study is to learn more about people with single ventricle heart disease. To do this, we need to collect genetic and health information from them. We also need to collect this information from their close family. This includes birth parents, siblings, and children.
summary.p5: We will ask you to answer questions about your health. We will ask you to sign a medical record release form. And we will ask you to send us a sample of your saliva (spit). We will use the spit sample for genetic testing. We will store your information securely. Researchers can use the information to study single ventricle heart defects. They can also use it to study many other diseases.
summary.p6: Researchers around the world can use the information. But the information will be “de-identified.” This means we will take out details such as your name and birth date. This makes it hard to identify you from the information. We will protect your privacy the best we can. But there is a small risk someone may see information that identifies you.
summary.p7: You will most likely not get any information back that is specific to you. The research may lead to ways to prevent and treat and other diseases.

intro.title: Introduction
intro.p1: Project Singular is a research study on single ventricle heart disease. We want to learn why some children are born with single ventricle heart defects. To do this, we need to collect genetic and health information from those with single ventricle heart defects. We also need to collect this information from their close family. This includes birth parents, siblings, and children.
intro.p2: Project Singular is paid for by Additional Ventures. Additional Ventures is a nonprofit foundation. Its goal is to learn about single ventricle heart disease.
intro.p3: We are asking you to take part in Project Singular for one of two reasons. You may have a single ventricle heart defect. Or you are a close family member (birth parent, sibling, or child) of someone with a single ventricle heart defect. This form will help you choose if you want to take part in the study. It will tell you what you will need to do if you choose to take part. It will also tell you the risks and benefits of taking part.
intro.p4: Let us know if you have any questions. If you do not understand something on this form, ask us. You can call us at (650) 761-6486. Or you can email us at contact@projectsingular.org.
intro.p5: You may talk about Project Singular with anyone. You may choose to take part in the study or not. It is important to know that it is your choice. You should know what your choice means for you. Do not sign this form until you are sure you want to take part in the study.

goal.title: What is the goal of Project Singular?
goal.p1: Right now, we don’t know how and why some children are born with single ventricle heart defects. We also don’t know why some people with this disease end up with other health problems. Project Singular is a research project. Our goal is to collect genetic and health information from people with different kinds of single ventricle heart defects. We also need to collect this information from some of their close family. This will help us learn what may cause the defects. We can also learn what may cause other related health problems.
goal.p2: Those who take part in Project Singular will need to send us a few things. We will need a saliva (spit) sample. If you are a single ventricle patient, we will also need information from your medical records. And we will ask you to fill out a survey to fill out. It will ask health questions. We will securely store all this information. The spit samples will be kept in a secure bank. The samples will be processed at the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard. This is a nonprofit biomedical research institute.
goal.p3: Researchers around the world can use the information. But the information will be “de-identified.” This means we will take out details such as your name and birth date. This makes it hard to identify you from the information. We will protect your privacy the best we can. But there is a small risk someone may see information that identifies you.

paying.title: Who is paying for this study?
paying.p1: Additional Ventures is paying for Project Singular. Additional Ventures is a nonprofit foundation. This means Additional Ventures does not make money (a profit) for its work on Project Singular.
paying.p2: The lead researcher for Project Singular works for Additional Ventures.

last.title: How long will Project Singular last?
last.p1: Project Singular does not have an end date. Our goal is for at least 5,000 people with single ventricle heart disease to take part in the study. We would also like many of their family members to take part. Researchers will be able access information from the study for a long time. We’re not sure how long yet.
last.p2: You can quit the study at any time. Please see the section “Can I quit Project Singular?” to learn more.

who_part.title: Who can take part in Project Singular?
who_part.p1: Any person diagnosed with a single ventricle heart defect can take part. The person must live in the United States or Canada.
who_part.p2: A close family member of a person with a single ventricle heart defect can take part. This includes birth mother, father, brother, sister, son, or daughter. The person must live in the United States or Canada.
who_part.p3: Any child that is a minor must have consent to take part. The child’s birth parent or legally authorized representative (such as a guardian) must give consent.
who_part.p4: Any adults with a single ventricle heart defect that are not able to give consent themselves must have consent from a legally authorized representative (such as a guardian) to take part.

need_part.title: What will I need to do if I take part in Project Singular?
need_part.p1: If you choose to take part, you will need to set up a secure account on www.projectsingular.org. You will need to fill out a survey. It will ask questions like your age, race, and gender. If you have a single ventricle heart defect, it will ask some questions about your diagnosis. And it will ask other things about your health.
need_part.p2: You will need to send us a sample of your spit. You will collect the sample using a kit we will mail to you and send the sample back to us. You won’t need to pay to mail it.
need_part.p3: You will need to send us contact information for your doctor. You will also need to sign a medical release form. This will allow your doctor to send us your medical records. The form will ask permission to collect and store your medical records now and in the future. That way we can update your health information. We will store this information in a secure online system. This information will be useful for researchers doing studies. Information shared with researchers will be “de-identified”. That means that details like your name and date of birth are removed to make it hard to link back to you.
need_part.p4: We can contact your doctor to ask for the medical records. Or you can ask your doctor for the records and send them to us. You can fax them to us. Or you can upload them through our secure website.
need_part.p5: We may call or email you if we need more information. We may contact you if your doctor needs you to sign more forms. We may send you reminders to complete surveys. Or we may need to let you know if there has been a major change to the study.
need_part.p6: We also may contact you in the future and ask if you want to take part in other research studies.

split.title: What will you do with my spit sample?
split.p1: When we receive your spit sample, we will do “whole genome sequencing.” This will give us a detailed look at your genes.
split.p2: Genes are parts of your DNA. Genes have instructions for how cells in your body should work and grow. We will study your DNA through “gene sequencing.” This is a way to read DNA. It lets us look for information in genes that may change the way your cells work. These changes may lead to different diseases. The goal of genetic research is to learn more about these diseases. We also want to find better ways to prevent, diagnose, and treat diseases.
split.p3: Sometimes researchers will only study a small part of DNA. They may look at just the part they know can cause a disease. We don’t know much about single ventricle heart disease, so we will look at all or most of your genes. This is called whole genome sequencing. It gives us a detailed look at all your genes. That way researchers can try to find which genes may play a role in single ventricle heart disease.

do_info.title: What will you do with my information?
do_info.p1: We will carefully store your information. We will use a secure online system. We will control access to the system. This means only doctors and researchers can view information in the system. The information will also be “de-identified.” This means we will take out details such as your name and birth date. This makes it hard to identify you from the information.

keep_info.title: How long will you keep my information?
keep_info.p1: Research is an ongoing process. We may want to use your information for future research. For this reason, we can’t set an exact time limit on how long we will store your information.

share_info.title: Who will have access to my information? What will they do with it?
share_info.p1: We may share your information with other researchers. But the information will be “de-identified.” This means the researchers won’t be able to identify you. This also means they can’t ask you if they can use your information in future studies. You won’t get to choose if your information is used in these studies. Some of these studies may be on diseases other than single ventricle heart disease. Some researchers may study ways to measure health. They may want to see how health might change with certain treatments or care. Some of these studies may be with for-profit companies for commercial uses. The companies may try to develop new treatments.

choices.title: What choices will I have for sharing my information?
choices.p1: If you take part in Project Singular, we will share your information with researchers. The information will be de-identified. Researchers that want to access the information will be approved by a scientific review committee. You won’t get to choose if you want to share your information with specific researchers. You can’t choose whether or not to take part in specific studies.
choices.p2: We may also need to share your information for business and legal reasons. We may share your health information with:
choices.li1: A limited number of Project Singular staff and contractors. This staff needs the information to do their jobs.
choices.li2: Federal regulatory or oversight authorities. For example, the U.S. Department of Health & Human Services.
choices.li3: An Institutional Review Board (IRB). This board makes sure we comply with your consent. The board also makes sure we do the study in the ways we said we would.
choices.p3: If you do not want us to share your information in these ways, you may quit the study at any time. To do this, call us at (650) 761-6486. Or email us at contact@projectsingular.org.

trial.title: Will you contact me if it looks like I might be eligible for a clinical trial?
trial.p1: No. We do not plan to contact you about clinical trials.

benefit.title: Will I benefit from taking part in Project Singular?
benefit.p1: You are not likely to directly benefit from taking part in Project Singular. But the information we collect from you may help research. The research may lead to better ways to prevent and treat single ventricle heart disease.

cost.title: How much does it cost to take part in Project Singular?
cost.p1: There is no cost to take part in Project Singular.

paid.title: Will I be paid for taking part in Project Singular?
paid.p1: No. You will not be paid for taking part in Project Singular. You will not be paid if research using your information results in new treatments, tests, or commercial products.

results.title: Will I find out the results of the research?
results.p1: You will most likely not get back any results specific to you or your family member with single ventricle heart disease. Also, your doctor will not get your results. You will not get any data files such as your genetic sequence.
results.p2: Right now, we don’t know which parts of DNA cause single ventricle heart defects. That’s why we’re doing this study. This means we don’t know which parts of your (or your family member’s) DNA may cause single ventricle heart disease. So we cannot give you any information about your (or your family member’s) genetic cause. In the future, we may make those discoveries. If we do, we may contact you. We may ask if you want information about your genetics specific to single ventricle heart disease. But we don’t know if or when this might be possible.
results.p3: Project Singular may provide a summary of research results. We may email you the summary. Or we may put it on our website. Single ventricle heart disease likely comes from many causes, which means not all results will apply to all patients--not even major discoveries. We may publish results, but the results may not be specific to your (or your family member’s) single ventricle heart defect.
results.p4: If we provide a summary of research results, we can’t answer questions about who specifically has which genetic cause. This is due to patient privacy.

other_results.title: Will I find out any other genetic results of the research?
other_results.p1: We want to understand the causes of single ventricle heart disease. To do this, we will look at every piece of your DNA. When we do, we may find changes in your DNA. These changes may be linked to some other disease that is not single ventricle heart disease. These findings are related to health conditions with known medical recommendations for health care providers to act upon with their patients. These results are called “secondary findings.” This type of result is not common. Most people in this study will not have a result like this.
other_results.p2: You have a choice. You can tell us now that you would like to know about a result like this. Then, if you have this type of result, we will contact you. We will connect you with a genetic counselor in your state. They will answer questions and help you understand what a secondary finding could mean for your health and decide whether you want to do a second genetic test to confirm the finding. This second test would be free of charge to you and will be paid for by Project Singular. If the finding is confirmed, the genetic counselor will work with you. They will help you understand what the finding means. They will help you understand what the next steps are for you. They can also arrange for other family members to be tested free of charge. At the end of this consent form, we will ask if you would want to know about a secondary finding.
other_results.p3: Currently, these secondary findings are not able to be returned to participants who live in Canada because of local and country guidelines. If guidelines change in the future and make it possible to return secondary results to Canadian participants, these results will be returned.

private.title: How will information about me be kept private?
private.p1: Your privacy is very important to us. We will take many steps to protect it. We will remove details from your information that could identify you. For example, we will take out your name and birth date. We will replace these details with a unique code number. We will do this before we share your information with researchers. We will also encrypt (scramble) your information when we store it. This makes it hard for people to see the information without permission.

risks.title: What are the risks of taking part in Project Singular?
risks.p1: There is a risk that someone may see your information without permission. There is a chance your information could be released by accident. This could identify you or your family. We think the chance of this is very small. But we can’t ensure absolute privacy.
risks.p2: You may learn that you have a genetic risk for a disease other than single ventricle heart disease. Although it’s not likely, it is possible. This may upset you. You might have to decide what to do. Your genetic information is unique to you. But you do share some genes with your parents, siblings, children, and other blood relatives. This means your genetic results could tell you something about your family. This might upset you or your family. Before you join the study, you may want to talk with your family. You may want to ask them if and how they want you to share any secondary findings with them.

part.title: Do I have to take part in Project Singular?
part.p1: No. Taking part in Project Singular is by choice. You can choose to take part or not. You can change your mind and quit at any time. Your choice will not affect your health care. There is no penalty for choosing not to take part in the study.

quit.title: Can I quit Project Singular?
quit.p1: Yes. You can quit Project Singular at any time. You can quit for any reason. If you quit, we will no longer share your information with researchers for future research studies. But we can’t take back any of your information that has already been shared.
quit.p2: To quit the study, you must tell us in writing. Contact the study staff at contact@projectsingular.org. If you choose to quit, it will not affect your health care now or in the future. There is no penalty for quitting.
quit.p3: You can quit the study and then choose to rejoin Project Singular in the future. But you will have to start over with the registration process.

info_removed.title: Can my information be removed from this research without my approval?
info_removed.p1: The lead researcher may decide your information is no longer needed for the research. In this case, we will remove your information. We will safely destroy any of your information that is not needed.

questions.title: What if I have questions, concerns, or complaints about Project Singular?
questions.p1: If you have questions, concerns, or complaints, let us know. If you think this research has hurt you or made you sick, contact us right away. You can call us at (650) 761-6486 (24 hours). Or you can email us at contact@projectsingular.org.
questions.p2: An Institutional Review Board (“IRB”) is overseeing this research. An IRB is a group of people that do independent reviews of research studies. You may reach them at (855) 818-2289 or researchquestions@wcgirb.com. Contact them if:
questions.li1: You have questions, concerns, or complaints and don’t get answers from the research team.
questions.li2: You can’t reach the research team.
questions.li3: You want to talk to someone else about the research.
questions.li4: You have questions about your rights as a research subject.

statement.title: Statement of Consent:

agree.title: This is what I agree to:
agree.li1: You may ask my doctor for my medical records. You may ask hospitals and other places where I received treatment in the past. You may ask where I am getting treatment now.
agree.li2: You may do genetic tests on my saliva sample that I will send you. You may store the sample until the tests are complete. You may link the results to my health information.
agree.li3: You may use my de-identified medical records and genetic test results for future research. (De-identified means that information like my name and date of birth have been removed to make it hard to link back to me.) It may be for studies not yet designed. It may be for studies on diseases other than single ventricle heart disease. It may be for studies for commercial uses.
agree.li4: You may store my de-identified medical records and genetic test results in a system with controlled access.
agree.li5: You may contact me in the future about this research study. You may contact me to ask me to sign more forms. These forms may be needed to let my hospital(s) share my medical records.

name.title: My full name below means:
name.li1: I have had enough time to read this form.
name.li2: I have thought about the information.
name.li4: I agree to take part in this study.
name.li5: I know that I can choose to take part in the study or not.
name.li6: I know that if I choose not to take part, it will not affect my health care.
name.li7: I know that I can choose to quit the study at any time.
name.li8: I know that a copy of the signed consent form will be on the project dashboard webpage. I may access it with my secure log in information. It will not be publicly available.
name.li9: By taking part in this study, I agree that my information may be used for different types of research.

statement.p1: I understand that when my genes are studied, changes in the genes may be found. These changes may be known to cause some diseases other than single ventricle heart disease. I understand that these results, called secondary findings, are very rare. These findings are related to health conditions with known medical recommendations for health care providers to act upon with their patients.
statement.p2: I understand that if you contact me about a secondary finding, you will connect me with a genetic counselor who will answer my questions and help me understand what a secondary finding might mean. They will arrange a second genetic test to confirm the result if I want to do that. This second test will be free of charge to me. If it is confirmed, a genetic counselor will tell me what the finding might mean. They will help me choose what next steps I might want to take. They can also arrange free testing for my family members if they are interested.
statement.p3: I understand that these secondary findings are not currently able to be returned to participants who live in Canada because of local and country guidelines. I understand that if guidelines change in the future and make it possible to return results to Canadian participants, these secondary results will be returned.

authorization.title: AUTHORIZATION TO USE AND DISCLOSE INFORMATION FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES
authorization.h1: What information may be used and given to others?
authorization.p1: Researchers, will be given your information. For example:
authorization.li1: Your de-identified past and present medical records (information such as name and date of birth will be removed).
authorization.li2: Your spit sample and de-identified genetic information.
authorization.h2: Who, may use and give out your information?
authorization.p2: The study staff may use and give out your information.
authorization.h3: Who else might access your information?
authorization.p3: The sponsor of this research may access your information. “Sponsor” is any person or company that is:
authorization.li3: Working, for or with the sponsor
authorization.li5: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA)
authorization.li6: Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) agencies
authorization.li8: The institution where the research is being done
authorization.li9: Governmental agencies to whom certain diseases (reportable diseases) must be reported
authorization.h5: Why will your information be used and/or given to others?
authorization.li13: To make sure that the research was done right.
authorization.p5: The results of this study may be made public. In this case, we will not use information that identifies you.
authorization.h6: What if I choose not to give permission to use and give out my information?
authorization.p6: Then you will not be able to take part in this research study.
authorization.h7: May I review or copy my information?
authorization.p7: Yes, but only after the research is over.
authorization.h8: May I take away (withdraw) my permission?
authorization.p8: This permission will be good until December 31, 2070.
authorization.p9: You may cancel your permission for us to use and share your information. You may do this at any time. Please send written notice to the study staff at contact@projectsingular.org. If you take away your permission, you won’t be able to remain in this study.
authorization.p10: When you withdraw your permission, no new information identifying you will be gathered after that date. We cannot take back Information that has already been shared.
authorization.h9: Is my information protected after it has been given to others?
authorization.p11: There is a risk that your information will be given to others without your permission.
authorization.p12: I have been told how my information will be used for this research study. I have been told who my information may be given to. My questions have been answered.
authorization.p13: I authorize the use and disclosure of my health information to the parties listed in the authorization section of this consent for the purposes described above.

consent_parental.name: Parental Consent
consent_parental.title:
PROJECT SINGULAR
RESEARCH CONSENT FORM

intro.p1: Parents/Guardians and Other Legally Authorized Representatives of Affected Children and Children Who Are Immediate Family Members of Affected Individuals
intro.p3: Principal Investigator: Kirstie E Keller, PhD
intro.p6: Please carefully read the consent form below. Click “Next” when you are done with each page. This will let you move to the next page. If you have questions about Project Singular or this form, please ask us. You can call us at (650) 761-6486. Or you can email us at contact@projectsingular.org.
intro.p7p2: a PDF version of the consent form and read it carefully.

consent_parental.summary_created: Signing this informed consent document is required if you wish to enroll your child.
consent_parental.summary_in_progress: Signing this informed consent document is required if you wish to enroll your child.
consent_parental.summary_complete: Thank you for signing the consent form!

summary.title: RESEARCH CONSENT SUMMARY
summary.p1: We are asking your child to take part in a research study. We are asking because your child or a close family member of your child (parent or sibling) has a single ventricle heart defect.
summary.p2: Taking part in the study is all by choice. You can choose if you want your child to take part or not. You can take your child out of the study at any time.
summary.p3: The goal of this study is to learn more about people with single ventricle heart disease. To do this, we need to collect genetic and health information from them. We also need to collect this information from their close family. This includes birth parents and siblings.
summary.p4: We will ask you to answer questions about your child’s health. You will need to sign a medical record release form. And we will ask you to send us a sample of your child’s saliva (spit). We will use the spit sample for genetic testing. We will store your information securely. Researchers can use the information to study single ventricle heart defects. They can also use it to study many other diseases.
summary.p5: Researchers around the world can use the information. But the information will be “de-identified.” This means we will take out details such as your child’s name and birth date. This makes it hard to identify your child from the information. We will protect your child’s privacy the best we can. But there is a small risk someone may see information that identifies your child.

intro.title: Introduction
intro.p1: Project Singular is a research study on single ventricle heart disease. We want to learn why some children are born with single ventricle heart defects. To do this, we need to collect genetic and health information from them. We also need to collect this information from their close family. This includes birth parents and siblings.
intro.p2: Project Singular is paid for by Additional Ventures. Additional Ventures is a nonprofit foundation. Its goal is to learn about single ventricle heart disease.
intro.p3: We are asking your child to take part in Project Singular. This is because your child or a close family member of your child (parent or sibling) has a single ventricle heart defect. This form will help you choose if you want your child to take part in the study. It will tell you what you will need to do if your child takes part. It will also tell you the risks and benefits of taking part.
intro.p4: Let us know if you have any questions. If you do not understand something on this form, ask us. You can call us at (650) 761-6486. Or you can email us at contact@projectsingular.org.
intro.p5: You may talk about Project Singular with anyone. You may choose to have your child take part in the study or not. It is important to know that it is your choice. You should know what your choice means for your child. Make sure we answer your questions before you choose. Do not sign this form until you are sure you want your child to take part in the study.

goal.title: What is the goal of Project Singular?
goal.p1: Right now, we don’t know how and why some children are born with single ventricle heart defects. We also don’t know why some people with this disease end up with other health problems. Project Singular is a research project. Our goal is to collect genetic and health information from people with different kinds of single ventricle heart defects. We also need to collect this information from their close family. This will help us learn what may cause the defects. We can also learn what may cause other related health problems.
goal.p2: Those who take part in Project Singular will need to send us a few things. We will need a saliva (spit) sample from your child. We will also need your child’s medical records. And we will send you a survey to fill out. It will ask health questions. We will securely store all this information. The spit samples will be kept at a secure gene bank. The samples will be processed at the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard. This is a nonprofit biomedical research institute
goal.p3: We will share the information with researchers around the world. But the information will be “de-identified.” This means we will take out details like name and birth date. This makes it hard to link information back to a person.

paying.title: Who is paying for this study?
paying.p1: Additional Ventures is paying for Project Singular. Additional Ventures is a nonprofit foundation. This means Additional Ventures does not make money (a profit) for its work on Project Singular.
paying.p2: The lead researcher for Project Singular works for Additional Ventures.

last.title: How long will Project Singular last?
last.p1: Project Singular does not have an end date. Our goal is for at least 5,000 people with single ventricle heart disease to take part in the study. We would also like many of their family members to take part. Researchers will be able access information from the study. They will be able access it for a long time. We’re not sure how long yet
last.p2: Your child can quit the study at any time. Please see the section “Can my child quit Project Singular?” to learn more.

who_part.title: Who can take part in Project Singular?
who_part.p1: Any person diagnosed with a single ventricle heart defect can take part. The person must live in the United States or Canada.
who_part.p2: A close family member of a person with a single ventricle heart defect can take part. This includes birth mother, father, brother, sister, son, or daughter. The person must live in the United States or Canada.
who_part.p3: Any child that is a minor must have consent to take part. The child’s birth parent or legally authorized representative (such as a guardian) must give consent.
who_part.p4: Any adults with a single ventricle heart defect that are not able to give consent themselves must have consent from a legally authorized representative (such as a guardian) to take part.

need_part.title: What will I need to do if my child takes part in Project Singular?
need_part.p1: If you choose for your child to take part, you will need to set up a secure account on www.projectsingular.org. If your child has a single ventricle heart defect, you will need to fill out a survey. It will ask about your child’s age, race, and gender. It will also ask about when your child was diagnosed. And it will ask other things about your child’s health.
need_part.p2: You will also need to send us a sample of your child’s spit. You will collect the sample using a kit we will mail to you. You will send the sample back to us. You won’t need to pay to mail it.
need_part.p3: You will need to send us contact information for your child’s doctor. You will also need to sign a medical release form. This will allow your child’s doctor to send us your child’s medical records. The form will ask permission to collect and store your child’s medical records now and in the future. That way we can update your child’s health information. This information will be useful for researchers doing studies.
need_part.p4: We can contact your child’s doctor to ask for the medical records. Or you can ask the doctor for the records and send them to us. You can fax them to us. Or you can upload them through our secure website.
need_part.p5: We may call or email you if we need more information. We may contact you if your child’s doctor needs you to sign more forms. We may send you reminders to complete surveys. Or we may need to let you know if there has been a major change to the study.
need_part.p6: We also may contact you in the future. We may ask if you want your child to take part in other research studies.

split.title: What will you do with my child’s spit sample?
split.p1: When we receive your child’s spit sample, we will do “whole genome sequencing.” This will give us a detailed look at your child’s genes.
split.p2: Genes are parts of your DNA. Genes have instructions for how cells in your body should work and grow. We will study your child’s DNA through “gene sequencing.” This is a way to read DNA. It lets us look for information in genes that may change the way your cells work. These changes may lead to different diseases. The goal of genetic research is to learn more about these diseases. We also want to find better ways to prevent, diagnose, and treat diseases.
split.p3: Sometimes researchers will only study a small part of DNA. They may look at just the part they know can cause a disease. We don’t know much about single ventricle heart disease. So we will look at all or most of your child’s genes. This is called whole genome sequencing. It gives us a detailed look at your child’s genes. That way researchers can try to find which genes may play a role in single ventricle heart disease.

do_info.title: What will you do with my child’s information?
do_info.p1: We will carefully store your child’s information. We will use a secure online system. We will control access to the system. This means only doctors and researchers can view information in the system. The information will also be “de-identified.” This means we will take out details such as your child’s name and birth date. This makes it hard to identify your child from the information.

keep_info.title: How long will you keep my child’s information?
keep_info.p1: Research is an ongoing process. We may want to use your child’s information for future research. For this reason, we can’t set an exact time limit on how long we will store your child’s information. When your child reaches the legal adult age, we will ask if your child wants to stay in the study. If your child does, he or she will review and sign a consent form. If your child wants to quit the study, your child can. If we try to contact your child at the time of adulthood and cannot reach him or her, we will continue to use and share any information already collected.

share_info.title: Who will have access to my child’s information? What will they do with it?
share_info.p1: We may share your child’s information with other researchers. But the information will be “de-identified.” This means the researchers won’t be able to identify your child. This also means they can’t ask you if they can use your child’s information in future studies. You won’t get to choose if your child’s information is used in these studies. Some of these studies may be on diseases other than single ventricle heart disease. Some researchers may study ways to measure health. They may want to see how health might change with certain treatments or care. Some of these studies may be with for-profit companies for commercial uses. The companies may want to develop new treatments.

choices.title: What choices will I have for sharing my child’s information?
choices.p1: If your child takes part in Project Singular, we will share your child’s information with researchers. The information will be de-identified. Researchers that want to access the information will be approved by a science review committee.
choices.p2: We may also need to share your child’s information for business and legal reasons. We may share the information with:
choices.li1: A limited number of Project Singular staff and contractors. This staff needs the information to do their jobs.
choices.li2: Federal regulatory or oversight authorities. For example, the U.S. Department of Health & Human Services and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA).
choices.li3: An Institutional Review Board (IRB). This board makes sure we comply with your consent. The board also makes sure we do the study in the ways that we said we would.
choices.p3: If you do not want us to share your child’s information in these ways, you may remove your child from the study at any time. To do this, call us at (650) 761-6486. Or, email us at contact@projectsingular.org.

trial.title: Will you contact me if it looks like my child might be eligible for a clinical trial?
trial.p1: No. We do not plan to contact you about clinical trials.

benefit.title: Will my child benefit from taking part in Project Singular?
benefit.p1: Your child is not likely to benefit directly from taking part in Project Singular. But the information we collect from your child may help research. The research may lead to better ways to prevent and treat single ventricle heart disease in the future.

cost.title: How much does it cost to take part in Project Singular?
cost.p1: There is no cost to take part in Project Singular.

paid.title: Will I or my child be paid for taking part in Project Singular?
paid.p1: No. Neither you nor your child will be paid for taking part in Project Singular. Neither you nor your child will be paid if research using your child’s information results in new treatments, tests, or commercial products.

results.title: Will I find out the results of the research?
results.p1: You will most likely not get any results specific to your child. Also, your doctor will not get your child’s results. You will not get any data files such as your child’s genetic sequence.
results.p2: Right now, we don’t know which parts of DNA cause single ventricle heart defects. That’s why we’re doing this study. This means we don’t know which parts of your child’s DNA may cause your child’s single ventricle heart disease. So we cannot give you any information about your child’s genetic cause. In the future, we may make those discoveries. If we do, we may contact you. We may ask if you want information about your child’s genetics specific to single ventricle heart disease. But we don’t know if or when this might be possible.
results.p3: Project Singular may provide a summary of research results. We may email you the summary. Or we may put it on our website. Single ventricle heart disease likely comes from many causes. That means not all results will apply to all patients. Not even major discoveries. We may publish results. But the results may not be specific to your child’s single ventricle heart defect.
results.p4: If we provide a summary of research results, we can’t answer questions about who specifically has which genetic cause. This is due to patient privacy.

other_results.title: Will I find out any other genetic results of the research?
other_results.p1: We want to understand the causes of single ventricle heart disease. To do this, we will look at every piece of your child’s DNA. When we do, we may find changes in your child’s DNA. These changes may be linked to some other disease that is not single ventricle heart disease. These results are called “secondary findings.” This type of result is not common. Most people in this study will not have a result like this.
other_results.p2: But we could find this result while looking at your child’s DNA. You have a choice. You can tell us now that you would like to know about a result like this. Then, if your child has this type of result, we will contact you. We will connect you with a doctor in your state. The doctor can do a second genetic test to confirm the finding. This second test would be free of charge to you. If the finding is confirmed, a genetic counselor will work with you. They will help you understand what the finding means. They will help you understand what the next steps are for your child. At the end of this consent form, we will ask if you would want to know about a secondary finding.
other_results.p3: Currently, these secondary findings are not able to be returned to participants who live in Canada because of local and country guidelines. If guidelines change in the future and make it possible to return secondary results to Canadian participants, these results will be returned.

private.title: How will information about my child be kept private?
private.p1: Your child’s privacy is very important to us. We will take many steps to protect it. We will remove details from your child’s information that could identify your child. For example, we will take out your child’s name and birth date. We will replace these details with a unique code number. We will do this before we share your child’s information with researchers. We will also encrypt (scramble) your child’s information when we store it. This makes it hard for people to see the information without permission.

risks.title: What are the risks from taking part in Project Singular?
risks.p1: You may learn your child has a genetic risk for a disease other than single ventricle heart disease. Although it’s not likely, it is possible. This may upset you. You might have to decide what to do. Your child’s genetic information is unique to him or her. But your child does share some genes with you. Your child also shares some genes with his or her other parent, brothers, sisters, and other blood relatives. This means your child’s genetic results could also tell you something about yourself or your family. This might upset you or your family. Before you join the study, you may want to talk with your family. You may want to ask them if and how they want you to share any secondary findings with them.

part.title: Does my child have to take part in Project Singular?
part.p1: No. Taking part in Project Singular is by choice. You can choose for your child to take part or not. You can change your mind. You can choose to remove your child from the study at any time. Your choice will not affect your child’s health care. There is no penalty for choosing not to take part in the study. Your child will not lose any benefits to which your child is otherwise entitled for not taking part.

quit.title: Can my child quit Project Singular?
quit.p1: Yes. Your child can quit Project Singular at any time. You can quit for any reason. If you choose to quit, we will no longer share your child’s information with researchers for future studies. But we can’t take back any of your child’s information that has already been shared.
quit.p2: To remove your child from the study, you must tell us in writing. Contact the study staff at contact@projectsingular.org. If you choose to remove your child from the study, it will not affect your child’s health care now or in the future. There is no penalty for quitting. Your child will not lose any benefits to which your child is otherwise entitled from quitting the study.
quit.p3: You can quit the study and then choose for your child to rejoin Project Singular in the future. But you will have to start over with the registration process.

info_removed.title: Can my child’s information be removed from this research without my approval?
info_removed.p1: The lead researcher may decide your child’s information is longer needed for the research. In this case, we will remove your child’s information. We will safely destroy any of your child’s information that is not needed.

child_legal_age.title: What are my child’s options when he or she reaches the legal adult age?
child_legal_age.p1: When your child reaches the legal adult age, we will ask if your child’s wants to stay in the study. If your child wants to stay, he or she will need to sign a consent form. If you child wants to quit, we will remove his or her information from the study. If we try to contact your child and cannot reach him or her, we will continue to use and share any information already collected.

questions.title: What if I have questions, concerns, or complaints about Project Singular?
questions.p1: If you have questions, concerns, or complaints, let us know. If you think this research has hurt your child or made your child sick, contact us right away. You can call us at (650) 761-6486 (24 hours). Or you can email us at contact@projectsingular.org.
questions.p2: An Institutional Review Board (IRB) is overseeing this research. An IRB is a group of people that do independent reviews of research studies. You may reach them at (855) 818-2289 or researchquestions@wcgirb.com. Contact them if:
questions.li1: You have questions, concerns, or complaints and don’t get answers from the research team.
questions.li2: You can’t reach the research team.
questions.li3: You want to talk to someone else about the research.
questions.li4: You have questions about your child’s rights as a research subject.

statement.title: Statement of Consent:
statement.li1: All children that are able must assent (agree) to take part in Project Singular. You will explain the study to the child. Then you will ask if your child agrees to take part. Some children may not be able to understand. If you determine this is the case, the child does not have to assent.
statement.li2: All children who assent must sign an assent form if they can. Some children may not be able to sign their name. If you determine this is the case, the child does not have to sign.

agree.title: This is what I agree to:
agree.li1: You may ask my child’s doctor for my child’s medical records. You may ask hospitals and other places my child received treatment in the past. You may ask places my child is getting treatment now.
agree.li2: You may do (or work with others to do) genetic tests on my child’s saliva sample that I will send you. You may store the sample until the tests are complete. You may link the results to my child’s health information.
agree.li3: You may use my de-identified medical records and results of my child’s genetic tests for future research. It may be for studies not yet designed. It may be for studies on diseases other than single ventricle heart disease. It may be for studies for commercial uses.
agree.li4: You may put my child’s de-identified medical records and results in a system with controlled access.
agree.li5: You may contact me in the future about this research study. You may contact me to ask me to sign more forms. These forms may be needed to let my child’s hospital(s) share my child's medical records.
agree.li6: You may collect my child's medical records until my child reaches the legal adult age. (The legal adult age is between 18 and 21 years old, depending on where you live.) At that time, my child can choose to consent or not. Medical records may be collected after my child reaches the legal adult age. But these records will only be from the time when my child was a minor.
agree.li7: If my child stays in the study until he or she reaches the legal adult age, you may contact my child to see if my child wants to stay in the study. You may contact me to get my child's contact information.

name.title: My full name below means:
name.li1: I have had enough time to read this form.
name.li2: I have thought about the information.
name.li4: I agree to have my child take part in this study.
name.li5: I know that I can choose for my child to take part in the study or not.
name.li6: I know that if I choose for my child not to take part, it will not affect my child’s health care.
name.li7: I know that I can choose to remove my child from the study at any time.
name.li8: I know that a copy of the signed consent form will be on the project dashboard webpage.
name.li9: By taking part in this study, I agree that my child’s information may be used for different types of research.

statement.p1: Your signature documents your permission for the individual named below to take part in this research.
statement.p2: I understand that when my child’s genes are studied, changes in the genes may be found. These changes may be known to cause some disease other than single ventricle heart disease. I understand that these results, called secondary findings, are very rare.
statement.p3: I understand that if you contact me about a secondary finding, you will connect me with a genetic counselor to arrange a second genetic test to confirm the result. If it is confirmed, the genetic counselor will tell me what the finding might mean. They will help me choose what next steps I might want to take. I understand that these secondary findings are not currently able to be returned to participants who live in Canada because of local and country guidelines. I understand that if guidelines change in the future and make it possible to return results to Canadian participants, these secondary results will be returned.

authorization.title: AUTHORIZATION TO USE AND DISCLOSE INFORMATION FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES
authorization.h1: What information may be used and given to others?
authorization.p1: Researchers will be given your child’s information. This may include:
authorization.li1: Your child’s past and present medical records.
authorization.li2: Records of your child taking part in research.
authorization.li3: Records of phone calls with you about your child for this study.
authorization.li4: Records of visits with your child for this study.
authorization.h2: Who may use and give out your child’s information?
authorization.p2: The study staff may give your child’s information to researchers.
authorization.h3: Who else might access your child’s information?
authorization.p3: The sponsor of this research may access your child’s information. “Sponsor” is any person or company that is:
authorization.li5: Working for or with the sponsor
authorization.h4: Your child’s information <u>may</u> be given to:
authorization.li7: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA)
authorization.li8: Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) agencies
authorization.li10: The institution where the research is being done
authorization.li11: Governmental agencies to whom certain diseases (reportable diseases) must be reported
authorization.h5: Why will your child’s information be used and/or given to others?
authorization.li15: To make sure the research was done right.
authorization.p5: The results of this study may be made public. In this case, we will not use information that identifies your child.
authorization.h6: What if I choose not to give permission to use and give out my child’s information?
authorization.p6: Then your child will not be able to take part in this research study.
authorization.h7: May I review or copy my child’s information?
authorization.p7: Yes, but only after the research is over.
authorization.h8: May I take away (cancel) my permission?
authorization.p8: This permission will be good until December 31, 2070.
authorization.p9: You may cancel your permission for us to use and give out your child’s information. You may do this at any time. Just send written notice to the study staff. If you cancel your permission, your child won’t be able to stay in this study.
authorization.p10: When you cancel your permission, no new information identifying your child will be gathered after that date. Information that has already been gathered may still be used and given to others.
authorization.h9: Is my child’s information protected after it has been given to others?
authorization.p11: There is a risk your child’s information will be given to others without your permission.
authorization.p12: I have been told how my child’s information will be used for this study. I have been told who my child’s information may be given to. My questions have been answered.
authorization.p13: I authorize the use and disclosure of my child’s information to the parties listed in the authorization section of this consent for the purposes described above.

consent_assent.summary_created: Please have your child read and sign this assent document, which is required if you wish to enroll your child.
consent_assent.summary_in_progress: Please have your child read and sign this assent document, which is required if you wish to enroll your child.
consent_assent.summary_complete: Thank you for signing the assent form -- your child is now enrolled!

content.p1: Please read or ask your child to read and then sign this assent document.
content.p2: We’re asking you to take part in a research study. The study wants to learn more about how hearts grow. We also want to find out why some hearts don’t grow the ways others do. A research study is a way for scientists to learn more about something.
content.p3: We’re asking you to take part because you or a family member has a special heart with a single ventricle heart defect. We want to learn more about this kind of special heart.
content.p4: If you agree to take part in this study, you’ll need to spit in a tube. Then mail the tube to us. We’ll study the stuff inside your spit.
content.p5: Inside your spit, there are cells. Cells make up every part of your body. These cells have information that tells your body how to grow. This information comes from instructions in your cells called genes.
content.p6: Each of us has our own genes that tell our body how it will look. Our genes tell the color of our eyes. They tell how tall we are. Sometimes genes give instructions that make it more likely for us to get a certain disease.
content.p7: We want to study the genes of people like you. We want to learn why some people have single ventricle heart defects. Doctors could use what they learn to better help people with these special hearts.
content.p8: If you join this research study, it may not help your health. But we may learn something to help others with single ventricle heart defects one day.
content.p9: You don’t have to take part in this study. It’s up to you. You can say yes now and change your mind later. Just tell your parent or guardian you want to quit the study. No one will be mad if you don't want to be in the study. And no one will be mad if you join and then change your mind and quit. Your doctor will still take good care of you no matter what you choose.
content.p10: If you have any questions, ask your parent or guardian to contact us. You can call us at (650) 761-6486 (24 hours). Or you can email us at contact@projectsingular.org.
content.p11: If you sign your name below, it means you agree to take part in this research study.

have_you_ever_been_on_ecmo.prompt: $ddp.checkAnswer("PATIENT_SURVEY_WHO_ENROLLING_HIDDEN","MYSELF", "Have you ever been on ECMO?", "Has your child ever been on ECMO?")

have_you_ever_had_a_ventricula.prompt: $ddp.checkAnswer("PATIENT_SURVEY_WHO_ENROLLING_HIDDEN","MYSELF", "Have you ever had a Ventricular Assist Device (VAD)?", "Has your child ever had a Ventricular Assist Device (VAD)?")

have_you_received_a_heart_transplant.prompt: $ddp.checkAnswer("PATIENT_SURVEY_WHO_ENROLLING_HIDDEN","MYSELF", "Have you received a heart transplant?", "Has your child received a heart transplant?")

have_you_received_a_liver_transplant.prompt: $ddp.checkAnswer("PATIENT_SURVEY_WHO_ENROLLING_HIDDEN","MYSELF", "Have you received a liver transplant?", "Has your child received a liver transplant?")

are_true_about_health.prompt: $ddp.checkAnswer("PATIENT_SURVEY_WHO_ENROLLING_HIDDEN","MYSELF", "Which of the following are true about your health in the past year?", "Which of the following are true about your child's health in the past year?")
are_true_about_health.been_prescribed: $ddp.checkAnswer("PATIENT_SURVEY_WHO_ENROLLING_HIDDEN","MYSELF", "I have been prescribed at least 1 new medication that I take every day", "My child has been prescribed at least 1 new medication that my child takes every day")
are_true_about_health.had_at_least: $ddp.checkAnswer("PATIENT_SURVEY_WHO_ENROLLING_HIDDEN","MYSELF", "I have had at least 5 sick visits to the doctor (not routine check-ups)", "My child had at least 5 sick visits to the doctor (not routine check-ups)")
are_true_about_health.been_hospitalized: $ddp.checkAnswer("PATIENT_SURVEY_WHO_ENROLLING_HIDDEN","MYSELF", "I have been hospitalized for a week or more", "My child has been hospitalized for a week or more")
are_true_about_health.have_missed: $ddp.checkAnswer("PATIENT_SURVEY_WHO_ENROLLING_HIDDEN","MYSELF", "I have missed 7 days or more from work or school due to illness", "My child has missed 7 days or more from work or school due to illness")

how_would_describe.prompt: $ddp.checkAnswer("PATIENT_SURVEY_WHO_ENROLLING_HIDDEN","MYSELF", "How would you describe your physical health?", "How would you describe your child's physical health?")

family_would_describe.prompt: $ddp.checkAnswer("PATIENT_SURVEY_WHO_ENROLLING_HIDDEN","MYSELF", "How do you think your family or close friends would describe your physical health?", "How do you think your family or close friends would describe your child's physical health?")

had_any_of_the_following_conditions.prompt: $ddp.checkAnswer("PATIENT_SURVEY_WHO_ENROLLING_HIDDEN","MYSELF", "Have you ever had any of the following conditions?", "Has your child ever had any of the following conditions?")
had_any_of_the_following_conditions.post_traumatic_stress_disorder: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) or other trauma-related distress

ever_had_a_neurodevelopmental.prompt: $ddp.checkAnswer("PATIENT_SURVEY_WHO_ENROLLING_HIDDEN","MYSELF", "Have you ever had a Neurodevelopmental or Neurocognitive Evaluation by a psychologist or other licensed professional?", "Has your child ever had a Neurodevelopmental or Neurocognitive Evaluation by a psychologist or other licensed professional?")
ever_had_a_neurodevelopmental.tooltip: A Neurodevelopmental or Neurocognitive Evaluation is a special set of tests by a licensed professional to assess a person's development and functioning, including their language or speech, motor skills, social skills, intelligence (IQ), attention, ability to do everyday tasks, and behavior.

diagnosed_by_a_physician.prompt: $ddp.checkAnswer("PATIENT_SURVEY_WHO_ENROLLING_HIDDEN","MYSELF", "Have you ever been diagnosed by a physician or licensed professional with any of the following?", "Has your child ever been diagnosed by a physician or licensed professional with any of the following?")
diagnosed_by_a_physician.communication_disorder: Communication disorder (such as language or speech sound disorder, social communication disorder)
diagnosed_by_a_physician.executive_function_difficulties: Executive function difficulties (for example, problems with planning, self-monitoring, self-control, time management or organization)

when_did_you_first_receive.prompt: $ddp.checkAnswer("PATIENT_SURVEY_WHO_ENROLLING_HIDDEN","MYSELF", "When did you first receive a diagnosis?", "When did your child first receive a diagnosis?")

received_education.prompt: $ddp.checkAnswer("PATIENT_SURVEY_WHO_ENROLLING_HIDDEN","MYSELF", "Have you received education support through school with an IEP or 504 Plan or early intervention services through your state or county?", "Has your child received education support through school with an IEP or 504 Plan or early intervention services through your state or county?")
received_education.tooltip: IEPs and 504 Plans are written documentation that provide either special education or related services (such as speech therapy) or plans of how the school will provide support or accommodations for students with disabilities.  Early Intervention is a support service available to babies and young children with developmental delays and disabilities.

received_treatment.prompt: $ddp.checkAnswer("PATIENT_SURVEY_WHO_ENROLLING_HIDDEN","MYSELF", "Have you ever received treatment or support for any form of emotional, behavioral, neurodevelopmental, or psychological problem?", "Has your child ever received treatment or support for any form of emotional, behavioral, neurodevelopmental, or psychological problem?")

who_received_treatment.prompt: $ddp.checkAnswer("PATIENT_SURVEY_WHO_ENROLLING_HIDDEN","MYSELF", "Who have you received this treatment or support from?", "Who has your child received this treatment or support from?")

living_with_a_behavioral.prompt: $ddp.checkAnswer("PATIENT_SURVEY_WHO_ENROLLING_HIDDEN","MYSELF", " In the past 2 weeks, how has living with a behavioral, neurodevelopmental, or mental health condition impacted your day-to-day life and wellbeing?", "In the past 2 weeks, how has living with a behavioral, neurodevelopmental, or mental health condition impacted your child's day-to-day life and wellbeing?")
